Projects



Undergraduate Thesis: Implementing speaker recognition using Student’s–t Mixture Model
January 2014 - June 2014

Mentored by Dr. Smriti Srivastava. Dr. Srivastava is a professor in the Division of Instrumentation and Control, Netaji Subhas Institute of Technology (NSIT) and also Dean, Undergraduate Studies, NSIT



Summer Intern, Viterbi School of Engineering, University of Southern California, USA
January 2014 - June 2014

I worked in the BioRC research project group led by Dr. Alice C. Parker in the Ming Hsieh School of Electrical Engineering. The target of the research group is to mimic the human brain’s neural structure through analog VLSI and nanotechnology. Within the BioRC group, involved with the C.Elegans project team with target to mimic the neural structure of C.Elegans worm. I worked in a team of three, with a masters student as the team head and the other member was another intern selected in the Viterbi Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE).

When I joined Dr. Parker’s research team everyone was building neurons manually which was very tedious and time consuming and also not very efficient especially because we are not sure of the design and structure and we constantly keep making changes. Following an idea of our team leader to automate the process of building the neuron structures using scripts, our team came up with the plan of using python and Shell scripts to create the structure. Later we integrated that with Ocean. We created and presented the prototype software functioning for one neuron in the research group meeting and a poster for the same was presented by my team-mate Chase Cook in the Poster Presentation organized for all SURE interns.
